qas.question: How have governments lowered infringement rates?

answers.text: narrowing the scope of what is considered infringing

qas.question: Besides upholding international treaty, what else have countries done specifically to digital works and uses?
What law in the US considers digital transmission of audio to be licensed if certain conditions are met?
What else does this law provide to service providers?

answers.text: providers whose users are suspected of copyright infringement

plausible_answers.text: narrowing the scope of what is considered infringing

qas.question: How have governments increased infringement rates?
Besides upholding international treaty, what else haven't countries done specifically to digital works and uses?
What law in the UN considers digital transmission of audio to be licensed if certain conditions are met?
What else doesn't this law provide to service providers?

plausible_answers.text: providers whose users are suspected of copyright infringement

context: Legislatures have reduced infringement by <a0_0><b5_0>narrowing the scope of what is considered infringing<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Aside from upholding international copyright treaty obligations to provide general limitations and exceptions, nations have <a1_0><b6_0>enacted compulsory licensing laws<b6_0/><a1_0/> applying specifically to digital works and uses. For example, in the U.S., the <a2_0><b7_0>DMCA<b7_0/><a2_0/>, an implementation of the 1996 WIPO Copyright Treaty, considers digital transmissions of audio recordings to be licensed as long as a designated copyright collective's royalty and reporting requirements are met. The DMCA also provides <a3_0><b8_0>safe harbor<b8_0/><a3_0/> for digital service <a4_0><b9_0>providers whose users are suspected of copyright infringement<b9_0/><a4_0/>, thus reducing the likelihood that the providers themselves will be considered directly infringing.
